segment.source: Shows how to implement a window for a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game and how to bring over the game loop, including how to build an IFrameworkView to control a full-screen CoreWindow.
segment.target: Shows how to implement a window for a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game and how to bring over the game loop, including how to build an IFrameworkView to control a full-screen CoreWindow.

segment.source: Port the game loop
segment.target: Port the game loop

segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.target: Summary

segment.target: Part 1: Initialize Direct3D 11

segment.target: Part 2: Convert the rendering framework

segment.source: Part 3: Port the game loop
segment.target: Part 3: Port the game loop

segment.source: Shows how to implement a window for a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game and how to bring over the game loop, including how to build an IFrameworkView to control a full-screen CoreWindow.
segment.target: Shows how to implement a window for a Universal Windows Platform (UWP) game and how to bring over the game loop, including how to build an IFrameworkView to control a full-screen CoreWindow.

segment.source: Part 3 of the Port a simple Direct3D 9 app to DirectX 11 and UWP walkthrough.
segment.target: Part 3 of the Port a simple Direct3D 9 app to DirectX 11 and UWP walkthrough.

segment.source: Create a window
segment.target: Create a window

segment.source: To set up a desktop window with a Direct3D 9 viewport, we had to implement the traditional windowing framework for desktop apps.
segment.target: To set up a desktop window with a Direct3D 9 viewport, we had to implement the traditional windowing framework for desktop apps.

segment.source: We had to create an HWND, set the window size, provide a window processing callback, make it visible, and so on.
segment.target: We had to create an HWND, set the window size, provide a window processing callback, make it visible, and so on.

segment.source: The UWP environment has a much simpler system.
segment.target: The UWP environment has a much simpler system.

segment.source: Instead of setting up a traditional window, a Windows Store game using DirectX implements IFrameworkView.
segment.target: Instead of setting up a traditional window, a Windows Store game using DirectX implements IFrameworkView.

segment.source: This interface exists for DirectX apps and games to run directly in a CoreWindow inside the app container.
segment.target: This interface exists for DirectX apps and games to run directly in a CoreWindow inside the app container.

segment.source: Note Windows supplies managed pointers to resources such as the source application object and the CoreWindow.
segment.target: Note Windows supplies managed pointers to resources such as the source application object and the CoreWindow.

segment.source: See [Handle to Object Operator (^)]https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/yk97tc08.aspx.
segment.target: See [Handle to Object Operator (^)]https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/yk97tc08.aspx.

segment.source: Your "main" class needs to inherit from IFrameworkView and implement the five IFrameworkView methods: Initialize, SetWindow, Load, Run, and Uninitialize.
segment.target: Your "main" class needs to inherit from IFrameworkView and implement the five IFrameworkView methods: Initialize, SetWindow, Load, Run, and Uninitialize.

segment.source: In addition to creating the IFrameworkView, which is (essentially) where your game will reside, you need to implement a factory class that creates an instance of your IFrameworkView.
segment.target: In addition to creating the IFrameworkView, which is (essentially) where your game will reside, you need to implement a factory class that creates an instance of your IFrameworkView.

segment.source: Your game still has an executable with a method called main(), but all main can do is use the factory to create the IFrameworkView instance.
segment.target: Your game still has an executable with a method called main(), but all main can do is use the factory to create the IFrameworkView instance.

segment.source: Main function
segment.target: Main function

segment.source: IFrameworkView factory
segment.target: IFrameworkView factory

segment.source: Port the game loop
segment.target: Port the game loop

segment.source: Let's look at the game loop from our Direct3D 9 implementation.
segment.target: Let's look at the game loop from our Direct3D 9 implementation.

segment.source: This code exists in the app's main function.
segment.target: This code exists in the app's main function.

segment.source: Each iteration of this loop processes a window message or renders a frame.
segment.target: Each iteration of this loop processes a window message or renders a frame.

segment.source: Game loop in Direct3D 9 desktop game
segment.target: Game loop in Direct3D 9 desktop game

segment.source: The game loop is similar - but easier - in the UWP version of our game:
segment.target: The game loop is similar - but easier - in the UWP version of our game:

segment.source: The game loop goes in the IFrameworkView::Run method (instead of main()) because our game functions within the IFrameworkView class.
segment.target: The game loop goes in the IFrameworkView::Run method (instead of main()) because our game functions within the IFrameworkView class.

segment.source: Instead of implementing a message handling framework and calling PeekMessage, we can call the ProcessEvents method built in to our app window's CoreDispatcher.
segment.target: Instead of implementing a message handling framework and calling PeekMessage, we can call the ProcessEvents method built in to our app window's CoreDispatcher.

segment.source: There's no need for the game loop to branch and handle messages - just call ProcessEvents and proceed.
segment.target: There's no need for the game loop to branch and handle messages - just call ProcessEvents and proceed.

segment.source: Game loop in Direct3D 11 Windows Store game
segment.target: Game loop in Direct3D 11 Windows Store game

segment.source: Now we have a UWP app that sets up the same basic graphics infrastructure, and renders the same colorful cube, as our DirectX 9 example.
segment.target: Now we have a UWP app that sets up the same basic graphics infrastructure, and renders the same colorful cube, as our DirectX 9 example.

segment.source: Where do I go from here?
segment.target: Where do I go from here?

segment.source: Bookmark the DirectX 11 porting FAQ.
segment.target: Bookmark the DirectX 11 porting FAQ.

segment.source: The DirectX UWP templates include a robust Direct3D device infrastructure that's ready for use with your game.
segment.target: The DirectX UWP templates include a robust Direct3D device infrastructure that's ready for use with your game.

segment.source: See Create a DirectX game project from a template for guidance on picking the right template.
segment.target: See Create a DirectX game project from a template for guidance on picking the right template.
